Project Proposal
Our project is based on Mini-Challenge 2 within the annual IEEE Visual Analytics Science and Technology (VAST) Challenge 2021. In January, 2014, the leaders of GAStech celebrated their new-found fortune from the initial public offering of their very successful company. In the midst of the celebration, several employees of GAStech went missing. Mini-Challenge 2 has provided vehicle tracking data and credit card purchases and preferences as recorded on loyalty cards of the GASTech employees 2 weeks before the disappearance to support the investigation.
The objective of this challenge is make use of visual analytics to identify which GASTech employees made which purchases and identify suspicious patterns of behavior from the datasets. We will make use of R and its packages, which are open-source and free, to visualize the data to make our findings accessible and replicable.
Datasets
There are 4 datasets provided:
Credit card data: transaction of each credit card with time stamp, price and location

Steps Involved
Getting a better sense of the spatio temporal data (credit card, loyalty and GPS)
Cleaning, transforming and merging the data
Choosing the best visualisations and R packages (maps or otherwise) for insight gathering
Allowing pre-determined inputs to allow flexibility and interactivity of the data and its visualisations
Engaging the reader to explore these visualisations on-demand within an RShiny app
Drafting poster for an overview of the process from scoping to actual implementation of the RShiny app
Using R to Visualise Spatio Temporal Data
Overview on Previous Works
ABC
What R Packages Will Be Explored?
Data Cleaning and Transformation
tidyverse Manipulation of the three types of data (credit card, loyalty and GPS)
timetk This package enables time-series visualisation. This includes anomaly detection and seasonality. This could facilitate the analysis to narrow down the suspicious employees.
geohashTools Allows lat long to be encoded into a short string of letters and digits to know which area on a map a user is within.
Interactive Data Visualisations
tmap Use to plot thematic maps. Thematic maps are geographical maps in which spatial data distributions are visualized.
ggplot2 Has a wide range of visualisations that can aid in analytics to understand the movement of the employees and the usage of credit card and loyalty data. Ggplot2 can be used for scatterplots, heatmap, timeseries and network graph visualisations.
plotly Use as a wrapper for ggplot2. Given the need for interactivity to identify the GASTech employees who made suspicious purchases and displayed abnormal patterns of behavior, plotly could be used for tooltips and animations.
ggiraph Allows ggplot graphics to be animated using tooltip, hover and on-click to help uncover suspicious activities.
ggraph Building on ggplot2, ggraph can provide greater detail and understanding of network data. For example, both credit card spending and car movements can be expressed using network graphs.
Interactive Web App
Shiny The use of Shiny allows for greater interaction between the user and the dataset.
Data Preparation
Data preparation largely follows the Mini-Challenge questions posed:
1. Data Cleaning
Check that dates and time are recognized correctly by R
Check that location names are not mis-spelt that create duplicates redundancies
For car-assignments data, replace car id blanks with 0 to indicate no car id.
2. Merging Data
Merging Credit Card And Loyalty Data To Form Transactional Dataset: Transactional dataset formed by joining both the credit card and loyalty data on date, location and amounts spent. To accommodate for possible errors in data inputs and difference in spend (e.g. due to mismatch due to cashbacks), we will use fuzzy matching to find the closest match between both datasets. This would give an indication of the loyalty number - credit card number relationship.
Location of Owner Using GPS dataset: Merge GPS dataset with car assignments dataset by ID. This will give an indication of the employees’ locations by car assignment. Travel patterns of employees assigned vehicles could be used to identify suspicious behavior and narrow down the suspects.
Identifying Movements By Merging GPS and Transactional Dataset: First, we will identify time pauses within the GPS data to discover where the employees were spending their time at. Then we can perform a visual inspection of these pauses in and their respective locations vis-a-vis the map. In addition, we can match the coordinates during the gps pauses against the location names in the transactional dataset to match the location on the map. This will help to connect the credit card and loyalty card owners to cars assignments.
User Takeaways
Allowing Users To Ask The Right Questions: Manipulating the data in a form that can be visualized on an interactive platform would allow the user to explore the data in greater detail. For a visual detective, this is key in uncovering anomalies or trends into what might have happened prior to the disappearances.
Giving Users The Dexterity To Explore A Hypothesis TBC - For this case, timetk would help with…cross reference network analysis to ..
Assumptions
Two Weeks Of Data Prior To The Disappearance Contains Valuable Clues: The challenge only provides these two weeks worth of data and alludes that this dataset showcases suspicious behaviour that are related to the eventual disappearance. It is also possible to suggest that suspicious activities may have occurred outside of these two weeks.
POI Locations Are Referenced Only From Map Image and Coordinates of Places with Spending: GPS movements through POI locations are visually approximated, after mapping the four corners of the map image onto a coordinate system. No availability of accurate POI coordinates.
Limitations
Data Limited To Two Weeks Prior To Incident: Apart from having data two weeks prior to the incident, obtaining data on the day of the incident would be equally, if not more, crucial in uncovering greater insights into what actually happened.
Limited Research On How Errors In Attributes And Locations Influence Both Spatio-Temporal Assessment And Pattern Analysis: The data extracted from the challenge has its own anomalies and its errors may skew its insights.
Additional POIs Gleamed From GPS Data Missing From Map: There are unknown POIs, derived from pauses in GPS data, that differ from the map. Though some POIs can be assumed as their residential points, other POIs would remain a mystery as to its actual nature.
Future Scope
Use Of Spatio-Temporal Statistics In Identifying Travel Patterns: Using existing GPS data, we can work a model of how possible a person is likely to be at a particular place at a point in time, given their job position and time of day
Time Series Anomaly Detection By Predictive Confidence Interval Anomalies can be detected using time series modeling. Specifically, building a predictive model using to understand the common trend for each employee. The predictive model could forecast future values with a confidence band. One suggested approach is to use ARIMA for each employee.
